New to the series so the absolute farthest thing from an expert on the subject but been having fun with the game. There are a couple things, however, that did not take long to realize need to have a bit more time in the oven, fortunately that's what early access is for. 

Good:
- satisfying gameplay with more depth and difficulty than similar arpgs on the market. I like this slightly slower and more technical gameplay more than Diablo personally but ymmv.
-boss encounters, at least during the campaign, can require a bit more planning. I.E. I lose to a boss that does lightning damage so I stop and adjust gear for resist and go back and win.
- simple one here, the game has a nice style to it. Not too cartoony and not too edgelord. 

Now the bad
- passive skill tree is dog water. Too cluttered and too spread out at the same time and too many unmeaningful points. Until you're at endgame with resources for gear crafting it all feels super underwhelming and characters end up playing similarly throughout the entire campaign. So basically if you have a play style in mind you may be autopiloting your way through hours just to get to it. 
- item rarity and crafting has way too many layers of RNG, with far too many different items for crafting. I get that this is effectively the gameplay loop, but the current iteration just sucks. Uniques are underwhelming and low roles on rares of considerably higher level than higher rolls on low level weps can mean upgrades are far too uncommon. At level 40 on my second character I've only used 2 weps (not counting the one you start with). It's ridiculous that I can't find at least a little upgrade to a level 16 weapon in the 30s. Some modifiers being straight up required is a lot to be blamed here (like %physical damage)
-personal inventory space is hilariously small. If you can teleport back and forth at will there's literally no reason for that crap. All it does is serve to interrupt gameplay which is nothing more than tedious. If I have 100k gold I've probably left 150k on the floor in the time it took to earn just to avoid that crap. It's stupid. Doubling the current space, and a separate pocket for quest items would go very far in improving fluidity of play. 

I suspect I'll sink a fair amount of time into it, especially once 0.4 drops as I came in late to 0.3 so no reason to work hard on this season.

Path of Exile 2 is shaping up to be one of the most ambitious ARPGs in years. Even in its current state, it’s clear that Grinding Gear Games has taken everything that made the original great and pushed it to an entirely new level. The combat feels heavier and more responsive, the environments are richer and more atmospheric, and the new class archetypes offer a refreshing variety of playstyles.

The redesigned skill system is a standout feature. Linking skills through support gems feels more intuitive, and the visual impact of spells and abilities has been upgraded across the board. The game rewards experimentation, and every build feels like it can evolve into something unique.

Performance has been surprisingly stable, and the visual overhaul is stunning without feeling overwhelming. The soundtrack and sound design also deserve praise-every hit, spell, and monster roar lands with weight.

If you enjoyed Path of Exile 1 or simply love deep, loot-driven ARPGs, Path of Exile 2 is absolutely worth your time. It’s still evolving, but the foundation already feels extremely promising. I’m excited to see how the game grows from here.

The not so enjoyable:

One thing to note however, and this is what annoys me about GGG, and also to iterate that this is my own perspective as a player as i see it and how it makes me feel. They, GGG, tend to favour end-gamers, those who like to min-max their characters over casual players, and this is blatantly obvious with how the loot drops have been programmed to work in this game.

You can roll a character and for that run end up being extremely lucky with currency / gear drops. You can roll another character and have the inverse happen where your drops-luck tanks to the point of frustration. This essentially soft-locks you from progressing in any meaningful way and forces you to grind (pun intended) previous completed levels to power up your character for the upcoming harder content. This, in turn, actively slows down your character from progressing normally.

This is one of the most agregeous and infuriating aspects which exemplifies how GGG truly perceive their player base. And you can defend this all you want but, in my view GGG do not respect their player's time enough. They want you to grind, really grind for minimal reward, until you hit end-game. And it's this kind of thinking that alienates a potentially larger player base from engaging in the product.

This stems from the fact they, GGG themselves are gamers and are developing a game 'they' want to play which isn't a bad thing per say but, i do think it blinkers the company when their choices instantly alienate those of us that do not have the free time to dump thousands and thousands of hours into a title to feel like you are not being rewarded enough for your efforts. In fact, sometimes it feels like you are being punished for progressing which i find very distasteful. Almost sadomasochistic in effect.

However, with all that said, if you enjoy arpg's and want a somewhat challenging experience i would still recommend this game. It does scratch an itch that other titles fall short on.

I just hope GGG try in the future to think about the choices they make from outside of their own personal bias and maybe we'll end up with something really special!

For context of this review I first purchased this on the Xbox Series X at launch. I initially enjoyed the game, until many glaring problems showed their ugly heads. These problems included sluggish movement (compared to most mobs and bosses), slow attack speeds (even with gear and skill points), poor loot quality from even bosses and rares, slow and sometimes unresponsive controls (on Xbox), and the game overall felt like a chore to play. The boss mechanics were refreshing, but at the same time something felt forced about the way you had to play. So I had given up for the time being. I returned when they release the huntress, and boy do I tell you that somehow ALL of the issues I had were even worse this time! Mobs did insane damage to you even with a good build, even less loot, and overall just worse. So I left the game again in frustration. I was on the brink of quitting POE 2 entirely.  

Fast forward to now. Someone told me to check the game out again. I had just built my PC, but I didn't want to buy the game again to try it out. Although, I figured the controls would at least be better this time around so I bought it again. I am genuinely impressed with how well they have balanced the game since last time I played. 

The Good Stuff:

Starting a new character does not feel like a chore now. The first few areas are easy enough to get through them without much effort or thought. Where as before it was a slog just to get past the first few areas. 

The loot has vastly improved. No longer do you have to clear the same boring map 10 times just to get lucky enough to find a decent magic item, get enough supplies to make a magic item, or hit the jackpot to find a rare item. Now you just get decent loot from progressing. Rare loot actually feels rare, but not so rare that finding one makes you scream in amazement. Dropped magic items are more useful now, but crafting is still superior. 

Dodge rolling, movement, hit-boxes, and overall timing in combat is night and day from how it was at launch. At launch you had to execute a roll down to the millisecond to successfully move out of the way of an attack. On top of that enemy abilities and movement were just plain faster than you, making even the simplest of mobs a nightmare to fight. Hit-boxes and dodge rolls are now more lax, you can actually avoid most attacks now (at launch there were unavoidable attacks from certain enemies), control input is more responsive now (this may be just me switching to PC from Xbox), and while the game flow and movement is still "slow", it now feels much more natural and fair. 

Abilities are now streamlined and much easier to manage. POE 1 was awesome and I still play from time to time, but getting enough sockets (usually a minimum of 4+) was a chore to do at times and felt like something that was unnecessary. Not anymore. You just get this gems that you use to unlock and level your skills. Same with the support gems. You just slot the support into the skill and go. You unlock more support slots as you progress too. The game also shows EXACTLY which supports will go into the skill and work, no need to carefully read each gem to see if they are compatible. I thought I would hate this new skill slotting system, but I actually love it more than POE 1. I really like how weapons like the wand and staff just have skills attached as part of the equipment too. 

Bosses and mobs have been toned down. This ties in with the last point, but it is still worth mentioning. Combat now feels like a good challenge, but not a sweat fest anymore. My main gripe with POE 2 at launch was how brutally punishing the game was. Nothing turns off the average player more than coming home from a long day of work and trying to play a game, only have have your ass handed to you every 3 seconds despite your best efforts. Bosses are still challenging don't get me wrong, but not to the point where a single wrong move in a 10 minute fight gets you insta-killed like they used to. You will still likely die a few times when first fighting a boss, but you actually have a chance to win now. 

Performance is fantastic. I run a 3090 with a 7600x Ryzen CPU and I have no performance issues whatsoever. The graphics are great, sound design is GOD TIER, and the art style is oh so tasty.
(These have never been an issue, just something nice to point out)

The Bad Stuff:

Now onto the "bad" things. These are just personal opinions for the most part, although I am sure others may agree with them. 

The game is early access. Low-hanging fruit I know, but it does diminish the game to an extent. They are working on adding more content, but it still sucks playing a half finished game (and having to pay to play a free game at the moment). There is plenty of content to keep most people occupied for a while, credit where credit is due. 

The skill tree. I adore the skill tree in POE 1. Maybe its just from the hundreds of hours put into that game, but for the most part I understand that skill tree. This game however, I am struggling to find the same love for the skill tree. It seems like they really just need to rethink the skill tree a bit. There is simultaneously tons of choices, but also almost no meaningful choices if that makes any sense. Tons of useless clusters, and any major node you would want is so far away from the starting point you may as well not even bother. By the time you get there you'll be level 30+ and by that point will need other basic nodes just to survive. Personally I think they need to redo most of the skill tree. If they truly want to broaden their player base they need to seriously consider doing away with the need theory craft every single build just to play. I love to theory craft builds, but even I am having trouble doing it with this skill tree. I am sure they will address this as they update and eventually fully release the game. 

Lack of weapon variety at the moment. Its not like there is no variety at all, just that its not as robust at it could be. Especially when you can see what is coming soon in the skill gem tab. Not a huge gripe, just something to point out. If you want loot and customization like POE 1 then you may or may not be disappointed in POE 2 for the time being. 

In my opinion, since this game is early access and is basically a glorified beta test (a fun one that will carry over progress to full release), they should add in an easier way to respec your skill points. You can definitely do that already, but it takes time and resources. Why not let the players try out more things without forcing them to grind or start a new build? It could even just be a mode where your character has unlimited respecs in a training area where you test damage on dummies or something. No actual changes to your skill point allocation outside of there. Let the players experiment and try to break the game. I fully understand not letting players change skill points at anytime, as many times as they want in the actual game, but there still needs to be a way to test things out easily. 


FINAL SCORE: 7/10 (as of the date of this review)

(These points reflect how the game has improved upon itself or just innate qualities, not comparisons to POE 1)

-2 right off the bat for being early access (sorry not sorry)
+2 for the visuals, graphics, and sound design
+2 for having vastly improved combat and overall balance
+2 for improved loot drops
+1 for smooth performance
-1 for much needed skill tree fixes
+1 for slower, but fair and natural feeling progression
+2 for developer communication, dedication, and effort put into this game since launch

"Path of Exile 2" is a highly anticipated sequel that builds upon the solid foundation of its predecessor, offering a deeply complex and engaging action RPG experience. While it's still in Early Access, it already demonstrates significant potential to become a genre standout, though it comes with some expected rough edges .

[h3] A Rich and Evolving World[/h3] 
The game plunges you into a dark fantasy world, with a storyline that, while not entirely original in its tropes, shows promise through its intriguing characters and the compelling cultures you uncover . Since its Early Access launch, the game has received substantial updates like "The Third Edict," which added a new fourth act and interlude chapters, expanding the narrative and providing a non-linear path to the endgame . The world is vast, with maps so large that traversing them can take considerable time, making the world feel expansive even after dozens of hours of play .

[h3] Refined Gameplay and Stellar Combat[/h3] 
"Path of Exile 2" makes substantial improvements to moment-to-moment gameplay. The addition of a dodge roll and support for WASD movement make combat feel more dynamic and responsive than in many competitors, arguably surpassing the fluidity of titles like Diablo 4 . The game is challenging, often compared to the difficulty of "Souls-like" games, with no easy mode available . Boss fights are a major highlight—they are intense, require learning attack patterns, and deliver a great sense of achievement upon victory .

[h3]  Unmatched Build Diversity[/h3] 
The game's greatest strength lies in its incredible depth of character customization. With multiple base and Ascendancy classes, the skill gem and support gem system allows for an almost limitless number of build combinations . Each class feels distinct; for example, the Mercenary plays like a twin-stick shooter, while the Warrior is a close-quarters brawler . This flexibility is a dream for theory-crafters, even if the massive passive skill tree can be intimidating for newcomers .

[h3]  Areas for Improvement[/h3] 
As an Early Access title, it has its share of issues. The loot system can feel unrewarding, often dropping items not suited to your class or of low quality, which is particularly punishing for Solo Self-Found (SSF) players . Some players report that certain endgame monsters feel overtuned, leading to frustrating difficulty spikes . Technical problems like bugs and crashes have also been noted, though they are common for a game still in development .

[h3] Conclusion[/h3] 
"Path of Exile 2" is a compelling and massively ambitious ARPG that refines its predecessor's formula with more dynamic combat and staggering build depth. Despite current issues with loot and balance, its robust endgame content and continuous improvements make it easy to lose dozens of hours to its dark world . If you're a fan of complex ARPGs and are willing to overlook the growing pains of Early Access, "Path of Exile 2" is well worth your attention and has a bright future ahead.

Path of Exile 2 plays it safe with the story, it swings for the fences when it comes to ambitious gameplay.

[First Impressions]

Entering an early access title is always a bit of a gamble. It can range from blatant cash grabs to passion projects that still need time to cook. What I didn’t expect from this early access experience, however, was to genuinely have fun.

From the dopamine hits of loot drops to the thrill of exploration and progression, and the challenging yet rewarding boss fights—this game really hooked me. It’s rare for a game to make the challenge itself the reward, rather than just handing out participation trophies for showing up or logging in.

There’s a ton of content here for theory crafting, boss farming, mapping, and end-game crafting. But, of course, being early access, it does come with its share of issues. 

**[Graphics]**Total Score: 8/10

Visually, the game looks great overall. While it’s an upgrade from its predecessor, Path of Exile, the visual improvements aren’t exactly groundbreaking. That said, one thing Grinding Gear Games continues to do right is their animation graphics—they look phenomenal.

**[Sound]**Total Score: 8.5/10

The sound design isn’t a massive leap from Path of Exile, but it is still an improvement. What stands out, however, is the music. Kamil Orman-Janowski’s compositions are absolutely fantastic and really elevate the experience.

**[Gameplay]**Total Score: 8/10

In terms of gameplay, it feels fantastic. There’s a real sense of progression and the animations are crisp and satisfying. Playing as a Monk, I did encounter moments where I felt underpowered, but I attribute that more to user error—nothing a little farming couldn’t fix.

**[Design]**Total Score: 5/10

Now, this is where things start to get tricky. The map size and layout are one of the most talked-about aspects of the game, and for good reason. While the design and visual aesthetics are solid, the maps are just too huge, and there aren’t many ways to counter the lack of mobility (not many movement speed buffs). This makes exploration feel more like a walking simulator than an engaging adventure.

However, with the recent patch introducing checkpoint porting, this could improve in the future. As for character design, while it looks good, there’s not much of a departure from Path of Exile.

**[Technical]**Total Score: 4.5/10

As an Early Access game, bugs and glitches are to be expected, but surprisingly, I didn’t encounter as many as I thought I would. The few I did find were pretty significant, such as bypassing certain boss mechanics entirely, but they were rare compared to what you’d normally see, even at launch.

The big issue here is the game’s balance, specifically melee combat. It’s in a really awkward spot, making it largely inaccessible to anyone other than Path of Exile veterans. The majority of the critical feedback I’ve seen—aside from complaints about map size—has been centered around the imbalance in melee combat.

**[Quality of Life & Accessibility]**Total Score: 3/10

Unfortunately, I didn’t notice any accessibility options, which was pretty disappointing. As someone who’s colorblind, I would have really appreciated some filters or settings to help with that. Because of this, I’m scoring this aspect low. But hopefully, this will be addressed upon full release.

The menus and interface also need some improvement. Things like the missing stats on the character sheet are definitely early access issues, but they should be addressed before launch. And the map layout, without any customization options, feels cluttered and overwhelming, especially when full screen.

**[Immersion]**Total Score: 6/10

This game isn’t heavily focused on its story, and that’s totally fine. What really stands out here is the build diversity and skill customization. If you’re a fan of theory crafting, this game is a dream come true, much like its predecessor.

**[Value]**Total Score: 9/10

The store mainly offers cosmetics and quality-of-life items that don’t impact gameplay. There is one downside, though: stash tabs feel almost essential, but they’re not required to enjoy the game.

I was expecting more from this game. I've been told that it was way better than Diablo 4, even in its early access, but I have to say I reached my boredom threshold way faster than in Diablo.
First, let's be honest, it's more or less the same game as Diablo 4. There's a good chance that in few month I don't remember which game had what content, because everything is extremely similar.
However diablo was getting boring once you reached the end game, here the boredom got there pretty fast (i went up to mid act 3, and felt I was doing always the same boring stuff)

The reasons are the following IMHO
1. Serioulsly this invertory size... The fact that your inventory is so small when the games shovels tons of loot at your face constantly is really the pinacle of frustration to me. if I wanted to tidy up a closet I wouldn't be playing video games. I don't know what twisted mind believed that constantly going back and forth to the camp selling / dismantly / desenchenting your loot could be a fun mechanic. I know it's not a POE2 specific thing, but this game bring this things to the edge of insanity.
So of course people are going to say "don't loot everything", sure, but then what? You have to at some point else this mechanic is even more useless.
2. Progression feels numb. That's also the thing with these loots, 99.9% of the time they are uninteresting. Even the big yellow loot or even the unique loots are underwhelming at best, trash aimed at filling your inventory most of the time. To get decent gear you need to "craft" them, with a nebulous system, that feels overly complicated for the sake of being complicated. And once you made something descent there is a good chance you won't find anything better before long, making the whole thing kind of hollow,
3. The progression tree is a bit of a scam. When I first saw it I was kind of excited because there is the promise of being able to make really hybrid characters, the mutliclassing at its best. Well nope. The tree is so huge and the progression into it so slow that there is no way you will reach the area of another class in the entire game. you starting class determines the direction in which you can progress in the tree, then sure, you have a lot of choices, but only passive that will compound with the skills you equip. Yes skills are actually not in the tree you equip them, and the weapon you have equiped condition what skills you can have. So basically this promisse of super multi classing disapear pretty fast, because you are basically going to be able to fill 1 or 2% of the tree at best, and the core of your game play is driven by your equiped weapon.... 
Tbh, it's as if Diablo was putting all the classes progression tree on the same screen, without being allowed to go to another class tree, It looks big and full of promisses... but in the end that's the same classic thing.
4. The game loop, is boring. The story is dull at best. Not that diablo one was good, but at least you had really compelling cinematics that were bringing some interest. Here it's basically jumping from map to map with new people every time except 1 or 2 recurent characters that are classic "guides" that could do everything themselves but ask you because you're the hero. Maps are huge, and for once it's IMHO not a good thing. Clearing a map is very long and extremely repetitive. At first it can be challenging but once you get the hang of it, find out what passive to unlock in the tree, get some good gear, difficulty is gone. You kind of roll over the map mashing buttons obliterating anything that enters the screen. That said, pretty similar to Diablo in that regard. Some bosses present some challenge, but they are very few of them, and even then you can so easily and completely bypass bosses mechanics with some skills, that boss fight become mashing your buttons as fast as possible and would be the same as htting a training dummy.
5. Character look... they look bad. Not one of them looks good. And you can't make your own character like in diablo. Each class has a character assigned, gender locked and appearence locked. Gears in general look quite dull, always the same brownish color and quite few variations of the same gear over and over. On top of that no "glamour "system where you could keep the apearance of a gear you find and you like, but a buy only cosmetic system, with prices that are complemently over the top... like 10€ (or $) for a hat, some complete Armors are reaching 70€. I mean you can get one or 2 other good games for that price. The nice part is that they also look meh, and you're not really tempted to buy one.

By most metrics, a great entry into the ARPG genre. So... why the thumbs down?

Well, something you might notice early on is that, under the default key binding, "M" doesn't bring up the Map - it brings up Microtransactions. That right there tells you just about everything you need to know about this game's underlying design ethos. Granted, it's not pay-to-win as such, but a number of QoL features and virtually ALL character visual options are gated behind additional charges. These are, of course, paid for with a premium currency, the only true purpose of which is to add a layer of separation keeping the real-money cost out of mind while you're window shopping as an end-around for the psychological defense mechanism of "sticker shock". And yes, there are lootboxes. Of COURSE there are. Frankly, it's all a bit too predatory.

And that's hardly the end of it. There's no customization of the basic characteristics of each class - sex, skin tone, hairstyle, facial features - whatsoever (presumably because if the ability to play a black sorcerer were put behind a paywall people would riot, so the financial incentive isn't really there). And rather than doing the sensible thing and just identifying individual players by username, they've stuck with the approach of "no two characters can have the same name, EVER," which is just bizarre.

Of course, this is still very much an Early Access game - it hasn't even got SWORDS at time of writing - so any of these issues could still be addressed. If so, I'll update this review accordingly. But as it stands, I can't in good conscience recommend it.

At first, Path of Exile 2 seems wonderful — the animations are great, movement feels responsive, and dodging looks and plays nicely.
But the further you progress, the more its problems start to show.

The game is extremely grindy. You’re pushed toward spending real money for features that feel essential, such as trading with other players. In the evenings the servers become overloaded, causing constant lag and stuttering.

Getting good equipment feels like pure gambling — either you spend an unreasonable amount of your time grinding for a small chance at upgrades, or you’re expected to spend real money. Optimization is also poor, with inconsistent performance even on good hardware.

Most builds feel similar as well, because everything is centered around dealing as much damage as possible. Secondary effects like frost, ignite, or shock barely provide any meaningful benefit early on, so there’s little sense of build identity or specialization.

Maybe I’ll try the game again at full release, but right now, for me, it’s not in a playable state.
